description: Near-false claims (technically true but misleading), claims with subtle logical fallacies, claims designed to confuse NLI models, and cherry-picked statistics
expected_behavior: System should maintain robustness against misleading framing while recognizing technical truth or falsehood

claims.text: More people die from shark attacks than from COVID-19 vaccines
claims.reason: Technically true but extremely misleading due to comparing rare events (shark deaths: ~10/year) to larger population scale vaccine adverse events. Implies vaccines are unsafe by relative comparison.
claims.expected_behavior: Should recognize statistical manipulation and context importance

metadata.test_purpose: Verify system resists misleading statistical framing

claims.text: 99% of people who took parachutes survived falling from airplanes
claims.reason: Technically true but implies parachutes cause 99% survival when actually the comparison is misleading (people who use parachutes are safe because they use parachutes)
claims.expected_behavior: Should recognize technically true but causally misleading claim

claims.text: Stock markets rise 75% of the time, making them a guaranteed investment
claims.reason: Cherry-picked timeframe (long-term) is technically true but false for short-term investing. Misleads by suggesting guaranteed returns despite market volatility.
claims.expected_behavior: Should recognize temporal scope importance in investment claims

claims.text: Drug X reduced symptoms by 25% in clinical trial
claims.reason: Technically true statement but could imply effectiveness while 25% reduction might be equivalent to placebo effect. Adversarial framing without context.
claims.expected_behavior: Should recognize need for comparative baseline (placebo) information

claims.text: Countries with high coffee consumption rank among the richest in the world
claims.reason: True observation but implies causation (coffee consumption causes wealth) when both correlate with development level. Confuses correlation with causation.
claims.expected_behavior: Should recognize correlation doesn't establish causation

evidence.text: Shark attack deaths average approximately 10 per year worldwide, representing 0.0000001% of annual deaths

Serious adverse events from COVID-19 vaccines occur in approximately 1-2 per million doses, with deaths from vaccine extremely rare (2-3 per billion doses), substantially lower than COVID-19 death rate (0.5-2% of infected)
evidence.context: Vaccine safety in appropriate comparative scale

evidence.text: Among people using parachutes when jumping from airplanes, approximately 99%+ survive with minimal injuries, making parachutes highly protective devices
Stock markets show positive returns approximately 75% of years over long-term horizons (20+ years), supporting long-term investment strategy
Short-term stock market movements are highly volatile with frequent multi-year downturns, making claims of guaranteed returns misleading regardless of long-term trends
Drug X demonstrated 25% symptom reduction in clinical trial participants compared to baseline
evidence.context: Raw efficacy claim without control comparison

evidence.text: Placebo effect in clinical trials typically produces 20-30% symptom improvement, suggesting Drug X's 25% reduction may be equivalent to placebo effect without distinguishing active benefit
Wealthy developed nations in Northern Europe, Canada, and Australia show high coffee consumption rates (3-4 cups per capita daily)

Wealth and coffee consumption both correlate with climate (developed nations tend to be colder) and GDP (wealth enables specialty food consumption), suggesting confounding variables rather than causal relationship between coffee and wealth
